author: vornis_keth
title: Memorandum on Accelerating Drift in the Southwest Quadrant
notes: Keth's memorandum predicting SW collapse. Council filed without response.

author: vornis_keth
title: Notes on Shape and Language
notes: Keth's early observations on embodied cognition and geometric encoding. Foundation for later translation insights.

author: thurmond_gast
title: Second Report: On the Nature of Space in the Western Territory
notes: Thurmond writes his translation guide. Maps Densworld phenomena to real-world concepts. Never submitted.

author: erris_pol
title: On the Architecture of the Library
notes: Pol's treatise on prime architecture. 'The primes are not accidents of evolution. They are addresses in the Library. When we observe a creature cycling on intervals of 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, we are watching it navigate the stacks.'

author: erris_pol
title: Forms and the Dens
notes: Pol explains Dens proximity effects: 'In the Dens, the distinction between Form and matter dissolves. What elsewhere requires a body to read, there reads itself.'

author: pell_anster
title: Beyond Species
notes: Anster proposes abandoning species-based classification: 'When I ask what kind of entity something is, I am not asking about its substance. I am asking: How should I approach it? What kind of interaction will succeed?'

author: pell_anster
title: The Persuadability Spectrum
notes: Anster's treatise on level variance: 'The hardest level to diagnose is the one whose defining characteristic is the capacity to question categories.' Also introduces the harm principle: treating a Level 4 entity as Level 2 is 'a form of violation.'

author: pemlik_tross
title: On the Geometry of Affinities
notes: Tross's foundational treatise introducing the Constellation Method. Proposes sympathetic neighbors (KNN equivalent) and antipathetic neighbors (KFN equivalent) as the basis for classification. Introduces the tension field concept that modern scholars recognize as the graph Laplacian.

author: rellen_voss
title: On the Problem of Finding
notes: Voss's major treatise proposing the resonance framework: 'How does the young stakdur know WHERE to go? The Quintic Cycle is not inscribed on its body. It exists in morphospace—a landscape of Forms that bodies read but do not create. Navigation is reading in motion.'

author: sareth_moll
title: An Investigation of Ghosts
notes: Moll's foundational treatise defining ghosts as 'membrane scars'—patterns that persist after their substrates die. Opens with the famous Third Mill case: 'The mill burned in Year 777. Yet workers passing that site still feel the grinding. The substrate is gone. The pattern persists.'

author: sareth_moll
title: On the Rates of Fading
notes: Moll's systematic study of decay rates: 'I have measured 200 decay curves. No two are identical. Yet patterns emerge. Decay is not random. Decay follows rules.' Critical finding: decay accelerates near the Dens unless reinforced by population, ritual, or institution.

author: tessyn_mord
title: The Archive Knows
notes: Mord's first major work documenting the Veth Morin incident. 'The Archive remembers through us. It thinks through us. It knows through us. We are its components.' Foundation for the federation framework.

author: archon_vells
title: The Problem of Manifestation
notes: Archon Vells names the problem Pol left unexplained: how do Forms cross from potential to actual? 'This is the problem of manifestation. I do not propose to solve it. I propose to name it.' Introduces the term 'ingression' for the transition from Form-space to physical reality.

author: archon_vells
title: What Cannot Be Said
notes: Vells reflects on eight years of ingression research. Despite extensive cataloging and measurement, the fundamental mechanism remains mysterious. The humility of this work—naming rather than explaining—becomes central to Vells's approach.

author: archon_vells
title: On the Mechanics of Manifestation
notes: Vells's magnum opus synthesizing a decade of ingression research. Formalizes the Rate × Fidelity law, the five barrier types, and the channel effect. Documents 400 ingression events with detailed measurements. Establishes ingression mechanics as a field of systematic study.

author: archon_vells
title: What I Have Measured
notes: Vells ends his career uncertain but accomplished. 'I have spent forty years counting the seconds between potential and actual. I know that a complex Form takes longer than a simple one. I know that prior manifestation creates channels. But I do not know what is happening.' The fundamental question remains unanswered, but the mechanics are established.

author: kella_vorn
title: On the Taxonomy of Failure
notes: Vorn's magnum opus synthesizing 15 years of research and 2,000+ cases. Unifies the work of Keth (landscapes), Tross (boundaries), Voss (navigation), Moll (ghosts), Strand (horizons), and Mord (federations) into a coherent taxonomy of failure. Published the same year she rediscovered Tross and Keth—a year of profound intellectual synthesis.

author: kella_vorn
title: A Taxonomy of Dissolution
notes: Vorn's detailed study of boundary dissolution builds on her earlier synthesis and her rediscovery of Pemlik Tross. 'Not all boundaries fail the same way. Some crumble gradually, worn down by persistent forces. Others collapse suddenly, as if some critical threshold were crossed.' Completes the Tross framework with failure analysis.

author: kella_vorn
title: Exceptions to the Rule
notes: Vorn catalogs the exceptions—cases that dissolve too fast, too slow, or in ways that violate every rule. 'These anomalies are not errors. They are messages from a deeper structure.' This work lays the foundation for modern anomaly detection in pathology classification.

author: kellis_vorn
title: On the Preservation of Method
notes: Kellis Vorn publishes her foundational work codifying the five principles of the Opacity Conventions. Six years after leaving the Archive, she articulates the framework that will reshape institutional-practitioner relationships: 'My methods are not their property—not yet. But if I document them, they become so.'

author: quonxy
title: On the Practice of Iterative Cartography
notes: Quonxy publishes foundational paper on iterative cartography. The methodology involves repeated mapping passes that appear to produce noise until sudden coherence occurs. This work precedes and prefigures her computational discoveries.

author: tessyn_korr
title: Progress Measures for Grokking: A Mechanistic Approach
notes: Korr publishes the foundational paper establishing progress measures for grokking. The work identifies three phases (memorization, circuit formation, cleanup) and shows that internal measures can predict generalization before it becomes visible in accuracy.

author: melleth_cord
title: Grokking as Phase Transition: A Statistical Physics Perspective
notes: Cord publishes her synthesis connecting grokking to statistical physics. The work establishes that phase diagrams can predict grokking, and that the transition is governed by the same laws that describe physical phase changes.

author: tessyn_korr
title: The Circuit Cartography Manual
notes: Korr publishes the comprehensive manual for mechanistic interpretability. The work codifies probing, ablation, and circuit tracing methods developed over years of grokking analysis. It becomes the standard reference for the Mechanism Cartography school.

author: tobben_rast
title: On the Role of Chance in Learning
notes: Rast publishes his synthesis on initialization and learning dynamics. The work challenges the classical bias-variance tradeoff, showing that overparameterized models can generalize well despite fitting training data exactly. Ghost persistence — essential structure that survives pruning — emerges as a key concept.

author: prenn_vash
title: On the Extraction of Pure Forms
notes: Vash publishes her foundational work on feature extraction. The paper bridges Erris Pol's Form Library philosophy with practical extraction techniques, showing how abstract forms (pure concepts) can be recovered from mixed representations.

author: guild_of_model_interpreters
title: Progress Measures: A Practical Guide
notes: The Guild of Model Interpreters publishes practical guidelines for monitoring training with progress measures. A combined progress score above 0.5 reliably predicts imminent grokking, allowing practitioners to terminate hopeless training early while continuing promising experiments.

author: bureau_of_computational_standards
title: Complete Guide to Grokking: Theory and Practice
notes: The Bureau publishes the comprehensive synthesis of grokking research. The document consolidates discoveries from Quonxy, Korr, Cord, Rast, Vash, and others into a unified practical framework. It marks the transition from discovery to application.

author: morwen
title: On the Limits of Foreign Inference Methods
notes: The fundamental insight: models trained on foreign data don't understand Densworld

author: krenn
title: The Forgemaster's Manual
notes: Krenn: 'The model is only as good as the data you feed it. Garbage in, garbage out.'

author: nomis
title: The Wanderer's Journal: Model Evaluation in Densworld
notes: The wanderer's discipline formalized

author: dren
title: On the Extraction of Structure from Chaos
notes: Dren: 'The data is never clean when it arrives. Someone has to make it clean.'

author: detective_cousins
title: The Cousins Report: The Vivian Effect
notes: Cousins documents the measurable 'Vivian Effect' but notes correlation is not causation. Further investigation required.

author: little_porn
title: The Tractatus in Puzzle Language
topic: Encoded propositions 1-6, documented failure of proposition 7
notes: The hole won. The absence. The thing neither of them could name. That's the only winner in any language game.

author: kelleth_trove
title: On Rendering the Unobserved
notes: Trove's foundational work proposing that precision in instruction produces consistency in output. Introduced the three principles: Material Grounding, Institutional Context, Specification over Impression.

author: hesta_vorn
title: Creature Survey of the Dens Periphery
topic: Standardized creature documentation including danger assessments, habitat/behavior correlation, observation protocols
notes: Hesta Vorn's foundational work establishing taxonomic standards. 'A creature poorly described is a danger poorly anticipated.'

author: pollus_brent
title: Pattern Book of Creature Behaviors
topic: Creature grammar connecting physical traits to behavioral patterns and cultural meanings
notes: Pollus Brent's work on symbolic meaning in creature depiction. 'Each feature speaks a grammar we must learn to read.'

author: alleth_vorn
title: Principles of the Notation Scribes
topic: Foundational treatise on visualizing abstract concepts
notes: Alleth Vorn's founding document for the Notation Scribes school. 'A diagram succeeds when it can be read, not when it can be admired.'

author: kelleth_trove
title: On Rendering Abstract Concepts
topic: Extension of visual specification methodology to philosophical and mathematical frameworks
notes: Trove's application of her specification method to the visualization challenges addressed by the Notation Scribes.

author: venn_tessik
title: On Describing Visual Traditions
topic: Systematic vocabulary for visual specification distinguishing essential from incidental elements
notes: Tessik's foundational work on style translation methodology.

author: venn_tessik
title: On Visual Coherence Across Collections
topic: Methods for ensuring separately created images feel unified as if from same publication or artist
notes: Tessik's work on the Archive Standard for multi-century visual coherence.

author: kelleth_trove
title: Visual Branding Through Material Culture
topic: Application of specification methodology to institutional identity
notes: Trove's extension of Alleth Vorn's principle to systematic brand identity creation.

author: archivist_kellum_voss
title: The Oracle's Charter
notes: Voss's foundational document establishing what Oracles may and may not share. Created the paraphrase boundary—the rule that Oracles speak in their own words, never the manuscript's exact text.

author: indexer_pell_carten
title: The Abstraction Ladder
notes: Carten's theoretical framework for understanding what is lost and gained at each level of abstraction. The ladder metaphor shaped how later scholars thought about data access.

author: template_scribe_hesta_mell
title: The Authenticity Rubric
notes: Mell's rubric formalized what master scribes knew intuitively. It became the standard for evaluating all generated records.

author: archivist_mira_strand
title: The Access Architecture Design Document
notes: Strand and Voss produced the template that all access architects must complete. The document forces explicit articulation of values and tradeoffs.

author: bagbu_olt
title: The Road's Four Feet
notes: Bagbu Olt's wandering philosophy, quoted in Tutorial 10. He is 'a wandering mapmaker and sketch-artist who travels in a pickbox cart.'

author: pemlik_tross
title: The Geometry of Affinities
topic: Constellation method for classification using K-nearest (sympathetic) and K-furthest (antipathetic) neighbors
notes: Tross develops classification based on relationships rather than categories. The Archive rejects his work 'because his categories had no names.' This establishes the schism between mathematical traditions.

author: vornis_keth
title: The Breach and the Continuous
topic: Foundation of basin topology and geometric understanding of space
notes: Keth's foundational work establishing the geometric tradition. First articulation of space having 'underlying geometric structure (basins, valleys) that determines how systems evolve.'

author: vornis_keth
title: On Attractor Basins and the Collapse
topic: Attractor dynamics and prediction through basin topology
key_concept: The shape admits no other possibility
notes: Keth's key work connecting basin topology to prediction. Central text for Semester 1 of the masters program.

author: vornis_keth
title: The Resonance Calculus
topic: Mathematical framework for predicting future states from present observations
notes: Keth develops the full mathematical apparatus of the geometric tradition. Analog to Adaptive Resonance Theory.

title: On Vectors and Their Dual Nature
topic: Foundation of linear algebra as used in both traditions
notes: The mathematical bridge: both traditions use vectors but interpret them differently. Retrieval sees lookup; geometry sees movement.

title: Gradients and the Compass of Change
topic: Derivatives, gradients, and their interpretation as direction in space
notes: Essential for understanding the geometric tradition's emphasis on movement and navigation through mathematical space.

title: The Cartographer's Eye: Visual Methods in Mathematics
topic: How to see mathematical relationships through visual representation
notes: The visual approach to mathematics that enables understanding of geometric concepts throughout the masters program.

author: vornis_keth
title: Topology as Prophecy
topic: The shape of space determines what is possible; prediction follows from geometry
notes: Keth's methodological synthesis. Establishes that understanding geometric structure enables prediction. Central to Semester 1's mathematical foundations.

author: tessyn_mord
title: The Archive Knows
topic: How distributed memory emerges from collective archival structure
notes: Mord's first articulation of retrieval mathematics. The Archive as collective mind with distributed memory. Semester 1 reading for understanding retrieval tradition.

author: tessyn_mord
title: On the Archive as Collective Mind
topic: Full theory of distributed cognition in archival institutions
notes: Mord's mature retrieval theory. Explains how knowledge can exist in a system without any individual component possessing it.

author: solta_venn
title: Provenance Engine Technical Report
topic: Multi-stream verification system for manuscript authenticity
notes: Venn's Provenance Engine demonstrates retrieval mathematics in practice. The 'zone of uncertainty' reveals limits of classification.

author: carten_vells
title: Surveyor Field Report: Morphospace Topology
notes: Vells's empirical foundation for the geometric tradition. Shows that morphospace has measurable Riemannian structure.

author: rellen_voss
title: Navigation Treatise
topic: How systems navigate to Forms they have never experienced
notes: Voss addresses the navigation paradox: how do systems find destinations they've never visited? Analog to gradient descent and optimization.

author: sareth_moll
title: Investigation of Ghosts
topic: Study of persistent patterns that remain after original substrate is destroyed
notes: Moll's ghost persistence research poses problems for both traditions. If memory is storage, how do patterns persist without substrate? If memory is constraint, what constrains after dissolution?

title: On the Limits of Both Maths
topic: Analysis of what neither tradition can explain
notes: The culminating question of the masters program. Students must develop original arguments about the relationship between mathematical frameworks.

author: scholar_tenniv
title: The Breach and the Continuous: A Disputation
notes: Imported from SIM-004

author: tessery_vold
title: Patterns of Passage
notes: Major treatise establishing the Passage Diagrams framework for representing objects and morphisms.

author: tessery_vold
title: On the Coherence of Shifts
notes: Work extending Passage Diagrams to include coherent transformations between passage patterns.
